node.title: Bridge and Road Repairs Ahead, but Where?
node.description: How will money from the infrastructure bill be spent? State and local officials have their wish lists.
node.content: ["It\u2019s Monday. We\u2019ll look at what the infrastructure bill will mean for New York. We\u2019ll also look at new delicatessens that are designed to look old.", "With President Biden expected to sign the $1 trillion infrastructure bill on Monday, it\u2019s time for specifics \u2014 specifically, what the bill could mean for the New York region. How will it jump-start road and bridge repairs? Where will the construction signs and detours be?", "The bill is expected to give several big mass-transit projects a green light, including an extension of the Second Avenue subway in Manhattan (with four new stations) and a plan for a new railroad tunnel between New York and New Jersey. The bill is also expected to help cover the cost of cleaning up contaminated ground water and improving sewers in New York City.", "The transportation-related funding in the bill, about 80 percent, is targeted at highways and road projects. Much of the rest will go to public transit. \u201cGiven that we\u2019re staring down a climate catastrophe,\u201d said Felicia Park-Rogers, the director of regional infrastructure projects for the Tri-State Transportation Campaign, a transit advocacy group, \u201cthis is not what we would like to see.\u201d", "But officials want to address drivers\u2019 gripes about deteriorating roads and bridges. Timothy Kennedy, a Democrat who chairs the State Senate\u2019s transportation committee, said that more than 1,700 bridges and 7,300 miles of highways and local roads in New York State are in poor condition. Money from the infrastructure bill would go a long way toward repairing them, he said. But state agencies will have some flexibility on spending and could use highway funds for bike lanes, said Kate Slevin, the executive vice president of the Regional Plan Association, an urban policy group.", "In New York City, Henry Gutman, the transportation commissioner, expects the bill to cover badly needed repairs to the well-worn Brooklyn-Queens Expressway, which is pummeled and pounded daily by 150,000 cars and trucks.", "Transit agencies are expected to spend much of the money they get on major projects, but not all involve shiny new train cars or state-of-the-art signal equipment. The Metropolitan Transportation Authority \u2014 which operates the subways and buses in New York, along with two commuter rail lines \u2014 will spend some of its $10 billion on making its system more accessible.", "Only about a quarter of the city\u2019s 472 subway stations are wheelchair-accessible now. Adding elevators and ramps is expensive in older stations.", "Another chunk of the M.T.A.\u2019s allocation could improve the Jamaica Station in Queens, built more than 100 years ago. Hundreds of thousands of Long Island Rail Road riders depend on the tangle of train lines that come together there every day.", "Of the 13 Republicans who supported the bill, four were from New York. On Long Island, a man was arrested Wednesday after making death threats against Representative Andrew Garbarino. The Washington office of Representative Nicole Malliotakis, whose district covers Staten Island and parts of Brooklyn, has received several angry phone calls.", "Representative Tom Reed, whose upstate district includes Corning and Ithaca, said his office had received several \u201caggressive\u201d calls about his vote. But he said he believed that most of his constituents supported the bill.", "\u201cA lot of what\u2019s driven this opposition was purely politically motivated,\u201d Mr. Reed said.", "Partly sunny with a slight chance of showers throughout the day and temps in the high 40s. Clear skies and windy at night with temps in the mid-30s.", "In effect until Nov. 25 (Thanksgiving Day).", "Nothing says \u201cNew York\u201d like a somewhat shabby shop that sells lox and bagels. But as the city\u2019s delicatessens were threatened with extinction, something happened. New look-alikes sprang up \u2014 delis designed to look old and authentic.", "New York was once a checkerboard of Jewish neighborhoods, with one or more kosher delis upholding Orthodox dietary strictures every few blocks. By one count, New York had upward of 1,500 Jewish delis in the 1930s. Undercut by changing demographics and a new aversion to the mainstays on their menus \u2014 fat, carbohydrates and salt \u2014 delis disappeared. The number dropped into the 10s.", "Now there are the look-alikes. \u201cFor those of us who grew up with the Jewish delis owned by our parents\u2019 or grandparents\u2019 generation, there\u2019s an upside and a downside to revisionist Jewish cuisine,\u201d Karrie Jacobs wrote in The Times\u2019s recent special section on design. \u201cOn the one hand, excellent bagels, lox and cured meats are now wonderfully easy to obtain. On the other hand, there\u2019s something slightly off-kilter about this attempt to resuscitate, through deft branding, the cranky, cerebral, irreverent Jewish culture that was once a dominant feature of New York City\u2019s character.\u201d", "She says the standard-bearer for these mixed emotions might be Frankel\u2019s Delicatessen & Appetizing in Greenpoint, Brooklyn. It was started five years ago by two brothers, Zach and Alex Frankel. The idea emerged after a long wait at Russ & Daughters, one of the last of the authentic places on the Lower East Side in Manhattan. Katz\u2019s Delicatessen, also on East Houston Street, is another.", "[The Rise of the Designer Deli]", "\u201cPeople would always ask us, do you think there\u2019s enough Jewish people who live in Greenpoint?\u201d Frankel recalled. Their reply: \u201cThat\u2019s not necessarily who we\u2019re building this for.\u201d Now, the clientele at lunch rush is \u201ca wild mix of, of characters,\u201d he said. They order more bacon than any other kind of meat.", "Another revisionist deli opened in Midtown Manhattan late last year \u2014 the USA Brooklyn Delicatessen, a couple of blocks from where the Carnegie Deli served overstuffed sandwiches until it closed in 2016. Owned by Shelly Fireman, who also created the Brooklyn Diner around the corner, its inspiration isn\u2019t Jewish food, per se, but the supremely marketable concept known as Brooklyn.", "Its Times Square-ish visual style was the work of the graphic designer Paula Scher. Karrie Jacobs writes that Scher\u2019s contribution to the emerging generation of Jewish-style delis is arguably an attempt to elevate pastiche into high culture. It \u201chad to scream \u2018deli,\u2019\u201d Scher said. But \u201cin an art way.\u201d", "The TriBeCa branch of Zuckers, a six-store chain that opened in 2006, is not exactly derivative of Jewish eateries \u2014 except for the logo, which suggests that Zucker\u2019s has been around forever. It was hand-drawn in 2016 by the restaurant branding firm Memo. Douglas Riccardi, the principal of Memo, said the message was that Zucker\u2019s \u201cis now firmly rooted in legacy, upholding the seminal New York bagels and lox mystique.\u201d", "Dear Diary:", "I was eating a sesame bagel and leisurely drinking coffee at a bagel shop when a young woman at an adjoining table asked if I would watch her laptop. She said she would be back shortly.", "A half-hour later, she had not returned.", "Two construction workers in hard hats sat down at the table she had vacated.", "\u201cI\u2019d like to ask you for a favor,\u201d I said to them, explaining about the laptop. \u201cI thought she went next door to the health food store. I have to leave.\u201d", "\u201cMaybe she went for a job interview,\u201d one of the men said.", "\u201cShe was properly dressed in a suit,\u201d I said. \u201cBut why not take her laptop along?\u201d", "\u201cMaybe she went to visit her boyfriend,\u201d the other man said.", "\u201cPossibly,\u201d I said. \u201cBut again, why not take the laptop along?\u201d", "\u201cWherever she is, she knows the laptop is safe with you,\u201d the first man said. \u201cBut we\u2019ll watch it.\u201d", "I thanked them and left. Later, I worried that I had not behaved responsibly. So, the next day I went to the bagel shop to make sure it was intact.", "To my relief, it was.", "\u2014 Helen Tzagoloff", "Illustrated by Agnes Lee.
